customer_addr:
3202 WEST SIERRA VISTA DRIVE
PHOENIX, AZ 85017

citations.narrative:
There was an excessive accumulation of cobwebs between enclosures for the adult cotton top tamarin and adult common
marmoset and the adjacent wall. The wall also had some small spots of dark debris stuck to it. There is not a regular
cleaning schedule for the walls and areas adjacent to the enclosures. Failure to clean areas surrounding enclosures
housing nonhuman primates as often as necessary can lead to exposure to disease agents and become a haven for
pests. Animal areas inside of housing facilities must be kept neat and free of clutter.
Correct by 14 December 2024.

During inspection, food stored in containers with tight fitting lids were taken out of the refrigerator and placed on a kitchen
counter directly adjacent to an open package of cigarettes, a lighter, and an ashtray filled with ash and used cigarettes.
The licensee was prepping fresh produce on the opposite counter in the kitchen. The inspector smelled a moderate odor
of environmental tobacco smoke in the kitchen. Storing substances that are toxic to nonhuman primates in food storage
and preparation areas may contaminate food fed to the animals and subsequently cause illness or injury. Supplies of food
must be stored in a manner that protects the supplies from spoilage, contamination, and vermin infestation.
Correct from this date forward of 12 December 2024.

citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
The enclosure for Loni, an adult cotton top tamarin, had excreta accumulating on the bottom interior surface. The licensee
stated that excreta is removed weekly from this enclosure. Failure to remove excreta daily from enclosures of nonhuman
primates may result in poor psychological welfare and exposure to disease causing agents. Excreta and food waste must
be removed from inside each indoor primary enclosure daily and from underneath them as often as necessary to prevent
an excessive accumulation of feces and food waste, to prevent nonhuman primates from becoming soiled, and to reduce
disease hazards, insects, pests, and odors.
Correct from this date forward of 12 December 2024.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
n

narrative:
3.75(b) 
   
Housing facilities, general. 
There was an excessive accumulation of cobwebs between enclosures for the adult cotton top tamarin and adult common 
marmoset and the adjacent wall. The wall also had some small spots of dark debris stuck to it. There is not a regular 
cleaning schedule for the walls and areas adjacent to the enclosures. Failure to clean areas surrounding enclosures 
housing nonhuman primates as often as necessary can lead to exposure to disease agents and become a haven for 
pests. Animal areas inside of housing facilities must be kept neat and free of clutter. 
 
Correct by 14 December 2024. 
3.75(e) 
   
Housing facilities, general. 
During inspection, food stored in containers with tight fitting lids were taken out of the refrigerator and placed on a kitchen 
counter directly adjacent to an open package of cigarettes, a lighter, and an ashtray filled with ash and used cigarettes. 
The licensee was prepping fresh produce on the opposite counter in the kitchen. The inspector smelled a moderate odor 
of environmental tobacco smoke in the kitchen. Storing substances that are toxic to nonhuman primates in food storage 
and preparation areas may contaminate food fed to the animals and subsequently cause illness or injury. Supplies of food 
must be stored in a manner that protects the supplies from spoilage, contamination, and vermin infestation. 
 
Correct from this date forward of 12 December 2024. 
3.84(a) 
   
Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control. 
The enclosure for Loni, an adult cotton top tamarin, had excreta accumulating on the bottom interior surface. The licensee 
stated that excreta is removed weekly from this enclosure. Failure to remove excreta daily from enclosures of nonhuman 
primates may result in poor psychological welfare and exposure to disease causing agents. Excreta and food waste must 
be removed from inside each indoor primary enclosure daily and from underneath them as often as necessary to prevent 
an excessive accumulation of feces and food waste, to prevent nonhuman primates from becoming soiled, and to reduce 
disease hazards, insects, pests, and odors.

Correct from this date forward of 12 December 2024. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
